definition:
If $a$ is an integer not divisible by a positive prime $p$, then
Fermat’s little theorem (a.k.a. Fermat’s theorem) guarantees that the
difference $a^{p-1}\!-\!1$ is divisible by $p$. The integer
$$q_p(a) \;:=\; \frac{a^{p-1}\!-\!1}{p}$$ is called the [*Fermat
quotient of $a$ modulo $p$*]{}. Compare it with the Wilson quotient
$w_p$, which is similarly related to Wilson’s theorem.\
[*Lerch’s formula*]{}
$$\sum_{a=1}^{p-1}q_p(a) \;\equiv\; w_p \;\, \pmod p$$ for an odd prime
$p$ connects the Fermat quotients and the Wilson quotient.\
If $p$ is a positive prime but not a Wilson prime, and $w_p$ is its
Wilson quotient, then the expression
$$q_p(w_p) \;=\; \frac{w_p^{p-1}\!-\!1}{p}$$ is called the
[*Fermat–Wilson quotient*]{} of $p$. Sondow proves in \[1\] that the
greatest common divisor of all Fermat–Wilson quotients is 24.
